School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Tiangong University Tianjin 300387 China To improve the low-temperature performance of V2O5/TiO2 catalysts in the selective catalytic reduction of ammonia (NH3-SCR), tungsten (W) and molybdenum (Mo) were incorporated into the V2O5/TiO2 catalyst. A series of V-W-Mo/TiO2 catalysts were synthesized using the incipient wetness impregnation method. Advanced characterization techniques, including Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), were utilized to examine the effects of WO3 and MoO3 co-doping on the performance of V/Ti catalysts. The findings reveal that the VW10Mo5.5/TiO2 catalyst demonstrated exceptional performance, maintaining a NO conversion rate above 80 % across a broad temperature range of 190 °C to 400 °C. In comparison, the V2O5/TiO2 catalyst required a temperature of 230 °C to achieve the same NO conversion rate, indicating that the co-doping of WO3 and MoO3 lowered the temperature for efficient NO conversion by 40 °C. Raman spectroscopy and XPS analyses revealed that the co-doping of WO3 and MoO3 increased the proportion of V4+ species and chemically adsorbed oxygen on the vanadium-titanium-based catalyst, which enhances low-temperature NH3-SCR activity. Furthermore, the co-doping of WO3 and MoO3 significantly affected the migration and aggregation of vanadium species, converting surface monomeric vanadium oxide species into surface polymeric vanadium oxide species. Polymeric vanadium oxide species are crucial for enhancing the NH3-SCR activity of the catalyst, with a high proportion of these species significantly boosting the NH3-SCR activity under low-temperature conditions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords V2O5/TiO2 catalyst WO3 MoO3 NH3-SCR Catalytic performance Data availability I have shared the link to my data at the Attach File step. 1 Introduction With the tightening of environmental regulations and the acceleration of industrialization, vanadium-titanium-based catalysts have played a pivotal role in reducing atmospheric pollution due to their superior denitrification performance [1–3]. Particularly in selective catalytic reduction (SCR) technology, they efficiently convert nitrogen oxides (NOx) into harmless nitrogen and water vapor, which is of great significance for controlling air pollution and protecting the environment [4–6]. However, despite the excellent performance of vanadium-titanium-based catalysts in the temperature range of 300-400 °C, their denitrification efficiency at low temperatures (<300 °C) still needs improvement, presenting a significant challenge in current research [7]. The promoting effect of tungsten oxide (WO3) on V2O5/TiO2 catalysts has been extensively studied [8–15]. Zhihui Lv and colleagues investigated the positive role of WO3 in the reduction of NOx by supported vanadium catalysts, confirming that WO3 occupies the surface of TiO2, reducing the available surface sites for V2O5 anchoring, thereby promoting the aggregation of vanadium oxide species and increasing the number of Brønsted acid sites [14]. Jaegers and his team revealed the structural impact of WO3 on supported V2O5/TiO2 catalysts, suggesting that non-reactive WO3 induces the formation of oligomeric vanadium oxide species, which are proposed as reactive sites for NOx reduction [8]. Similarly, molybdenum oxide (MoO3) has been demonstrated to be a catalyst promoter for NH3-SCR reactions due to its ability to accelerate electron transfer and improve surface acidity [16–22]. Min Gie Jung and colleagues investigated the effects of incorporating Sb, La, Ce, and Mo additives into high vanadium-content V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalysts on NH3-SCR, proving that Sb, La, Ce, and Mo enhance the reaction activity, which is attributed to the increased V4+(3+) ratio and the enhancement of surface-adsorbed oxygen species [16]. Kobayashi and others reported that by incorporating MoO3 into TiO2-SiO2, highly active polymeric vanadium oxide species are formed, which exhibit significant activity at low temperatures [17]. Previous studies have demonstrated that single doping with WO3 or MoO3 alters the acid amount and acid strength of V2O5/TiO2 catalysts, which significantly influence catalytic performance. In this study, we investigated the co-doping of WO3 and MoO3 to expand the regulation range of acid amount and acid strength in V2O5/TiO2 catalysts by adjusting the dosage and ratio of WO3 and MoO3, thereby improving denitration performance. Moreover, single doping with WO3 or MoO3 was found to have a dispersion threshold; beyond this critical threshold, WO3 or MoO3 tended to agglomerate, forming crystalline phases that reduced the acid amount. However, co-doping with WO3 and MoO3 increased the loading of dopants while maintaining a highly dispersed state, thereby enabling precise control over the acid amount, acid strength, and active sites of V2O5/TiO2 catalysts. This paper prepared V2O5-WO3-MoO3/TiO2 catalysts using the incipient wetness impregnation method and adjusted the ratio of WO3 to MoO3 in the catalysts. The NH3-SCR performance was tested, and characterization techniques such as Raman spectroscopy, XPS, N2 adsorption-desorption, NH3-TPD, and H2-TPR were used to analyze their physicochemical properties. This allows researchers to better understand the physicochemical properties of these catalysts, thereby providing a scientific basis for further optimization of their denitrification performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalyst A series of V2O5-WO3-MoO3/TiO2 catalysts were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method. The content of V2O5 is 3.5 wt%. A certain amount of ammonium metavanadate (NH3VO3) (99 %, Macklin), ammonium metatungstate ((NH4)10H2(W2O7)6) (analytical purity, Damao), and ammonium molybdate ((NH)6Mo7O24) (99 %) are dissolved in deionized water and impregnated into TiO2 (97 %) to prepare. Dry the obtained sample overnight at 100 °C and calcine at 500 °C for 3 hours. A series of VWxMoy/TiO2 catalysts with different doping ratios of WO3 and MoO3 were synthesized, where x and y represent the mass fractions of WO3 and MoO3, respectively. For example, VW10Mo5.5/TiO2 corresponds to a catalyst containing 10 wt% WO3 and 5.5 wt% MoO3. 2.2 Characterization The Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer (XRD) (Rigaku, Japan) was used to characterize the crystal structure of the catalyst. The detection parameters were: scanning voltage 40 kV, scanning current 150 mA, sample scanning speed: 5°/min, and angle range: 20°∼80°. Autosorb-IQ-C-MP automatic physical-chemical adsorption instrument was used to determine the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of the catalyst. NH3-TPD and H2-TPR were measured by a Micrometrics AutoChem2920II chemisorption instrument. NH3-TPD test protocol: a sample mass of 500 mg was used. The sample was first heated to 500 °C in helium at a heating rate of 10 °C/min and held for 2 hours to remove impurities. Ammonia adsorption was conducted at 80 °C using 20 % NH3/He for 60 minutes. The sample was then purged with argon at 80 °C for 30 minutes, followed by heating to 600 °C in nitrogen at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. H2-TPR test protocol: a sample mass of 500 mg was used. The sample was first heated to 500 °C in helium at a heating rate of 10 °C/min and held for 2 hours to remove impurities. The temperature was then lowered to 100 °C, and the sample was purged with He for an additional 30 minutes. Subsequently, the sample was heated to 900 °C in 10 % H2/He. XPS was performed on a NEXSA (Thermos Fisher, USA) X-ray photoelectron spectrometer to determine the elemental composition of the catalyst surface. 2.3 NH3-SCR activity test The NH3-SCR denitrification performance was assessed in a fixed-bed reactor system (Fig. 1 ), comprising three modules: (1) gas distribution unit, (2) tubular quartz reactor (10 mm inner diameter), and (3) online flue gas analyzer. Gas concentrations (NO, NO2, N2O, CO2, NH3 ,H2O) were tracked in real time using an MKS FTIR analyzer. The simulated flue gas contained 2000 ppm NO, 2000 ppm NH3, 5 % O2, 5 % CO2, 5 % H2O and N2 as balance gas. Experiments were performed at a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 14,000 h⁻¹, with temperature programmed from 100 °C to 400 °C (heating rate: 5 °C·min⁻¹). NO conversion and NH3 conversion were calculated as: X N O ( % ) = [ N O ] i n − [ N O ] o u t [ N O ] i n × 100 % X N H 3 ( % ) = [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N H 3 ] o u t [ N H 3 ] i n × 100 % N 2 S e l = 1 − [ N O 2 ] o u t + 2 [ N 2 O ] o u t [ N O ] i n + [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N O ] o u t − [ N H 3 ] o u t × 100 % where: [NO]in, [NH3]in: Inlet concentrations (ppm) [NO]out, [NH3]out: Outlet concentrations (ppm) 3 Results 3.1 NH3-SCR performance As shown in Fig. 2 (a), under 150 – 400 °C, GHSV = 14,000 h⁻¹ conditions, the V/Ti catalyst achieved 80 % NO conversion at 230 °C, demonstrating moderate-temperature activity but limited performance below 200 °C. MoO3 doping significantly enhanced low-temperature activity, reducing the 80 % NO conversion threshold (T80) to 198 °C. Subsequent WO3 co-doping further broadened the operational temperature window and shifted its lower limit with increasing WO3 loading. The optimized VW10Mo5.5/Ti catalyst exhibited >80 % NO conversion across 190–400 °C, showcasing superior low-temperature performance (Fig. 2(b)). However, an excessively high WO3 loading (e.g., 15 wt%) led to a decrease in NO conversion rate, indicating that there was an optimal range for the WO3 loading amount. Systematic MoO3 content optimization (Fig. 2(c)) revealed that the T80 values for VW10/Ti (0 wt% MoO3) and VW10Mo10/Ti (10 wt% MoO3) were 210 °C and 209 °C, respectively. In contrast, the VW10Mo5.5/Ti catalyst achieved T80 at 190 °C, confirming that 5.5 wt% MoO3 represents the optimal doping level for maximizing low-temperature efficiency. Fig. 2(e) and (f) presented the N2 selectivity curves of vanadium-titanium-based catalysts with varying W and Mo contents. The results showed that samples doped with WO3 and MoO3 exhibited excellent N₂ selectivity across the temperature range of 150-400 °C, consistently maintaining selectivity levels above 96 %. 3.2 Structural analysis Through in-depth analysis of the XRD patterns in Fig. 3 , it is observed that the four catalysts exhibit highly consistent characteristic diffraction peaks at 25.24°, 37.8°, 48.06°, and 62.72°. By comparing with the standard JCPDS card for anatase TiO2 (PDF#44-0477), these peaks are identified to correspond to the (101), (004), (200), and (204) crystal planes of anatase TiO2, respectively, confirming the dominant anatase phase in all catalysts [23–25]. Notably, despite the introduction of V, W, and Mo oxide promoters into the catalyst system, no characteristic diffraction peaks of V2O5 or MoO3 were detected in any samples except for the VW15Mo5.5/Ti sample. This absence may be attributed to either the loading amounts of these oxides being below the detection limit of X-ray diffraction or their existence as highly dispersed amorphous species on the TiO2 support surface [24]. Further investigation revealed that when the WO3 doping level reached a critical value (as exemplified by the VW15Mo5.5/Ti sample), distinct diffraction peaks emerged at 23.86° and 34.02°, which corresponded to the (002) and (202) crystal planes of WO3 (PDF card #43-1035), respectively. This phenomenon indicated that excessive doping induced localized aggregation of WO3, leading to crystalline phase formation. At lower loading levels, W species tended to atomically disperse or form ultra-small nanoclusters uniformly distributed across the TiO2 surface. However, when the loading exceeded the monolayer dispersion capacity of the support, surplus W species underwent lattice migration and aggregation, ultimately crystallizing into WO3 particles. N2 adsorption-desorption analysis was systematically performed on the four samples to investigate their textural properties, with the experimental results presented in Fig. 4 . Detailed examination of the N2 physisorption isotherms revealed that all samples exhibited characteristic Type IV isotherms with H3-type hysteresis loops [26]. This distinctive combination conclusively demonstrates the existence of well-developed mesoporous structures in the catalysts - a crucial feature for catalytic applications as it promotes abundant active sites and facilitates efficient mass transport during reactions [27]. The specific surface area of the V/Ti catalyst was measured to be 95.1 m2/g. Upon doping with MoO3 and WO3, a decreasing trend was observed in the specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size. This suggests that MoO3 and WO3 may exist as oxide nanoparticles attached to the inner walls, leading to the reduction in specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size, as shown in Table 1 . Of particular interest was the VW10Mo5.5/Ti catalyst, which exhibited the most promising NH3-SCR performance despite exhibiting relatively moderate textural parameters (surface area = 86.1 m2g⁻¹, pore volume = 0.30 cm3 g⁻¹). This apparent paradox suggests that the remaining accessible surface area in VW10Mo5.5/Ti remains sufficient to sustain exceptional catalytic efficiency. 3.3 Acid sites Fig. 5 displays the NH3-TPD profiles of the vanadium-titanium catalyst series, revealing three distinct desorption peaks between 100-600 °C. The low-temperature peak (Peak I) corresponded to NH3 adsorbed on weak acid sites, including physically adsorbed NH3, while the medium-temperature peak (Peak II) was attributed to NH3 bound to medium acid sites. The high-temperature peak (Peak III) originated from NH3 associated with strong acid sites [28–30]. Experimental characterization showed that the introduction of MoO3 increased the amount of medium and weak acid sites while reducing that of strong acid sites, resulting in an overall increase in total acidity, consistent with previous reports [31,32]. When MoO3 and WO3 were co-doped, compared with the V2O5/TiO2 catalyst, the peak II area corresponding to the medium acid sites significantly increased, indicating that the introduction of MoO3 and WO3 enhanced the medium acid amount of the catalyst, thereby improving its low-temperature NH3 adsorption capacity. Meanwhile, the desorption peak temperature of peak III, corresponding to the strong acid sites, shifted toward lower temperatures, suggesting that the co-doping altered the distribution of strong acid sites and reduced the desorption energy barrier of NH3 on these sites, making it easier for NH3 to be activated at low temperatures and participate in the reaction. Notably, when the MoO3 content reached a threshold value, a further increase in WO3 loading could additionally elevate the acid amount. However, NH3 adsorption capacity showed a non-linear relationship with WO3 loading - initially increasing then decreasing at higher concentrations (15 wt%). As quantified through Gaussian deconvolution in Table 2 , the NH3 adsorption capacities followed the order: VW10Mo5.5/Ti > VW5Mo5.5/Ti > VW15Mo5.5/Ti > VMo5.5/Ti. The optimal WO3 loading (10 wt%) in VW10Mo5.5/Ti achieved maximum NH3 adsorption capacity, which correlated with enhanced low-temperature NH3-SCR activity. The capacity reduction at 15 wt% WO3 likely stemmed from WO3 agglomeration and crystalline WO3 formation, as supported by complementary BET surface area measurements and XRD patterns discussed earlier. This particle aggregation phenomenon reduced effective surface area and consequently diminished NH3 adsorption capability. 3.4 Redox properties The reducibility of vanadium-titanium-based catalysts with varying WO3 loadings was systematically investigated by H2-TPR analysis (Fig. 6 ). Five distinct reduction peaks were observed in the temperature range of 300-900 °C, each corresponding to specific redox processes. Peak I (400-450 °C) was attributed to the reduction of surface-isolated V5+ species, as previously documented in literature. Peak II (450-500 °C) corresponded to the Ti4+→Ti3+ reduction process. The broad Peak III centered at 600 °C represented overlapping reduction events involving both the reduction of polymeric V5+ species and the sequential reductions of Mo6+→Mo4+ and W6+→W4+. Subsequent high-temperature reductions were observed as Peak IV (750-800 °C) for Mo4+→Mo0 and Peak V (800-850 °C) for W4+→W0 [33,34]. A notable shift in reduction temperatures was observed with increasing WO3 content. The VW10Mo5.5/Ti catalyst exhibited the most optimal reducibility, exhibited the lowest peak center temperatures (Peak I: 399 °C, Peak II: 462 °C, Peak III: 575 °C, Peak IV: 782 °C, Peak V: 803 °C). This enhanced reducibility, particularly in the critical low-temperature region below 600 °C, strongly correlates with its superior low-temperature NH3-SCR performance [35,36]. The hydrogen consumption quantification revealed a progressive increase in H2 consumption with WO3 loading, reaching maximum value of 2.5850 mmol/g for VW10Mo5.5/Ti. However, when WO3 loading exceeded 15 wt%, both reduction temperatures and H2 consumption exhibited counterintuitive trends – the former shifted to higher temperatures while the latter decreased significantly, as shown in Table 3 . This reversal suggested that excessive WO3 doping induced agglomeration of tungsten species, forming bulk-like WO3 crystallites that reduced interfacial contact and hindered hydrogen accessibility. The evolution of peak intensities provides further mechanistic insights. With increasing WO3 content, the reduction peak intensity of surface-isolated V5+ (Peak I) species gradually decreases, while the intensity of Peak III showed a significant enhancement. This observation suggested the potential formation of surface polymeric vanadium oxide species. It was widely recognized that polymeric vanadyl species served as the predominant active sites, playing a decisive role in governing low-temperature SCR activity [37–40]. This proposed structure-activity relationship will be further corroborated by Raman spectroscopic analysis in subsequent sections. To investigate the surface vanadium species evolution and electronic states of vanadium-titanium-based catalysts, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were performed. Fig. 7 (a) and 7(b) display the O 1s and V 2p core-level spectra, respectively. The O 1s spectra exhibited two distinct peaks: lattice oxygen (Oβ) at 530.5–530.8 eV and surface-adsorbed oxygen (Oα) at 532.0–532.3 eV [41]. Oα demonstrated superior activity owing to its enhanced electron transfer capability, which promoted NO oxidation to NO2 and facilitated active intermediate formation in the NH3-SCR cycle [42,43]. Consequently, higher Oα content significantly improved low-temperature NH3-SCR performance. The Oα/(Oα+Oβ) ratios follow the order: V/Ti (21.1%) < VMo5.5/Ti (25.5%) < VW10Mo5.5/Ti (27.1 %) < VW15Mo5.5/Ti (29.5 %) < VW10Mo5.5/Ti (30.3 %). Compared with V/Ti, the introduction of 5.5 wt% MoO3 elevated the Oα ratio to 25.5 %, while co-doping with 10 wt% WO3 maximized this value (30.3 %), correlating with optimal low-temperature activity. This enhancement arose from MoO3 and WO3 modulating oxygen speciation, where moderate doping increased surface-adsorbed oxygen content and redox capacity. However, excessive WO3 loading (15 wt%) reduced the Oα ratio to 29.5 %, likely due to tungsten agglomeration and surface site blockage. The V 2p spectra revealed two peaks at 514–521 eV. Deconvolution of the V 2p region yielded components at 518.2–518.7 eV (V5+) and 516.8–517.0 eV (V4+) [44]. The reduced V4+ species, with excess electrons, enhanced surface electron mobility and promoted O2 adsorption/activation, critical for low-temperature SCR reactions [45].The V4+/(V4++V5+) ratios increased sequentially: V/Ti (66.6 %) < VMo5.5/Ti (77.4 %) < VW5Mo5.5/Ti (79.0 %) < VW10Mo5.5/Ti (80.5 %), aligning with their NH3-SCR activity trends. This confirmed that synergistic WO3-MoO3 doping optimized vanadium redox properties through structural interactions. At 15 wt% WO3 loading (VW15Mo5.5/Ti), the ratio declined to 78.1 %, indicating that excessive doping induced active site aggregation, reduced reactant-catalyst contact area, and diminished catalytic efficiency. 3.5 Surface vanadium species As shown in Fig. 8 , the Raman results indicated that all catalysts exhibited five bands at 636 cm⁻¹, 514 cm⁻¹, 395 cm⁻¹, 196 cm⁻¹, and 143 cm⁻¹, which were attributed to signals from anatase TiO2 [46]. Further examination in the range of 900-1100 cm⁻¹ revealed weak but distinct signals, which could be deconvoluted into three peaks. The bands at 1035 cm⁻¹ and 930 cm⁻¹ corresponded to monomeric vanadium oxide species and polymeric vanadium oxide species, respectively, while the peak at 969 cm⁻¹ was attributed to the Raman signal of Mo=O species [47–50]. Analysis of the Raman spectra of the four samples showed that the V/Ti catalyst primarily exhibited signals from monomeric surface vanadium oxide species. Upon the addition of Mo species, a signal for Mo=O species appeared at 969 cm⁻¹, and a signal for polymeric vanadium oxide species emerged at 930 cm⁻¹. This indicated that the addition of MoO3 indeed promoted the formation of polymeric vanadium oxide species on the surface, which was consistent with the NH3-TPD results. When both W and Mo species were introduced, a more intense signal for polymeric vanadium oxide species was observed at 930 cm⁻¹. This suggested that the incorporation of W and Mo species further promoted the aggregation of monomeric surface vanadium oxide species into polymeric forms, likely due to the partial occupation of TiO2 surface sites by W and Mo species, which caused vanadium species to come into closer proximity. However, when the W content in the catalyst reached 15 wt%, the signal for polymeric vanadium oxide species began to weaken. Polymeric vanadium oxide species exhibited higher NH3-SCR activity compared to monomeric surface vanadium oxide species. The increased number of polymeric vanadium oxide species in the VW10Mo5.5/Ti catalyst contributed to its superior low-temperature NH3-SCR activity. 4 Discussion The synergistic co-doping of WO3 and MoO3 effectively enhanced the low-temperature NH3-SCR performance of vanadium-titanium catalysts. In V2O5/TiO2 catalysts, the active sites for NH3-SCR reactions primarily consisted of V5+=O species, which adsorbed NH3 and reacted with NO to form the (-NH2NO) intermediate, ultimately converting it into N2. Meanwhile, certain acid sites (e.g., V–OH) served as NH3 reservoirs. Although these sites did not directly participate in the reaction, they promoted NH3-SCR by increasing NH3 adsorption capacity [29]. NH3-TPD results showed that when MoO3 and WO3 were co-doped, compared with the V2O5/TiO2 catalyst, the peak II area corresponding to the medium acid sites significantly increased, indicating that the introduction of MoO3 and WO3 enhanced the medium acid amount of the catalyst, thereby improving its low-temperature NH3 adsorption capacity. Meanwhile, the desorption peak temperature of peak III, corresponding to the strong acid sites, shifted toward lower temperatures, suggesting that the co-doping altered the distribution of strong acid sites and reduced the desorption energy barrier of NH3 on these sites, making it easier for NH3 to be activated at low temperatures and participate in the reaction. Furthermore, the co-doping of WO3 and MoO3 synergistically enhanced the V4+/(V5++V4+) ratio (reaching 80.5 % in VW10Mo5.5/Ti) and Oα proportion (30.3 %), which accelerated two critical processes: electron transfer and O2 activation. These steps were essential for NO oxidation and intermediate formation. The WO3-MoO3 co-doping induced the aggregation of surface monomeric vanadium oxide species, forming polymeric vanadium oxide species (Scheme 1 ). Notably, these polymeric vanadyl species exhibited significantly higher activity than their monomeric counterparts, playing a decisive role in low-temperature SCR performance. These results aligned with recent studies emphasizing the importance of acid-redox bifunctionality in SCR catalysts [16], The structural evolution induced by WO3-MoO3 co-doping further elucidated the "dispersal-aggregation" threshold phenomenon. At low loading levels, W species achieved atomic-level dispersion or formed uniformly distributed ultra-small nanoclusters on the TiO2 surface. However, exceeding this threshold triggered WO3 agglomeration (as evidenced by XRD and BET data), physically blocking active sites and deteriorating the redox cycle. This phenomenon explained the paradoxical decline in hydrogen consumption (2.5850 → 2.1120 mmol/g) and V4+ content (80.5 % → 78.1 %) at 15wt % WO3 loading, underscoring the delicate balance required in the design of multicomponent catalysts. 5 Conclusion In this study, a series of V-W-M/TiO2 catalysts were synthesized via the incipient wetness impregnation method. by introducing tungsten (W) and molybdenum (Mo) elements into a V2O5/TiO2 base catalyst. The NH3-SCR performance of these catalysts was systematically investigated, with the VW10Mo5.5/Ti catalyst exhibiting optimal low-temperature activity, achieving >80 % NO conversion across a broad temperature window of 190–400 °C. NH3-TPD results demonstrated that the VW10Mo5.5/Ti catalyst possessed the highest acid amount, which facilitated NH3-SCR reactions by increasing NH3 adsorption capacity. H2-TPR and XPS analyses revealed that this catalyst exhibited superior low-temperature reducibility (as evidenced by an isolated V5+ reduction peak at 399 °C), which was beneficial for promoting the acid cycle. The highest V4+ content (80.5 %) and Oα proportion (30.3 %) were found to facilitate electron transfer and O2 activation. Raman spectroscopy further confirmed that WO3-MoO3 co-doping drove the transformation of monomeric vanadium species into highly active polymeric vanadium species, while excessive WO3 loading reduced the formation of these polymeric species. The exceptional performance of VW10Mo5.5/Ti was ascribed to its enhanced acidity, optimized redox properties, and abundant polymeric vanadium species. In contrast, excessive MoO3 or WO3 doping was found to disrupt this balance through aggregation, diminished redox performance, and structural disorder. coredata.dc:description: To improve the low-temperature performance of V2O5/TiO2 catalysts in the selective catalytic reduction of ammonia (NH3-SCR), tungsten (W) and molybdenum (Mo) were incorporated into the V2O5/TiO2 catalyst. A series of V-W-Mo/TiO2 catalysts were synthesized using the incipient wetness impregnation method. Advanced characterization techniques, including Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), were utilized to examine the effects of WO3 and MoO3 co-doping on the performance of V/Ti catalysts. The findings reveal that the VW10Mo5.5/TiO2 catalyst demonstrated exceptional performance, maintaining a NO conversion rate above 80 % across a broad temperature range of 190 °C to 400 °C. In comparison, the V2O5/TiO2 catalyst required a temperature of 230 °C to achieve the same NO conversion rate, indicating that the co-doping of WO3 and MoO3 lowered the temperature for efficient NO conversion by 40 °C. Raman spectroscopy and XPS analyses revealed that the co-doping of WO3 and MoO3 increased the proportion of V4+ species and chemically adsorbed oxygen on the vanadium-titanium-based catalyst, which enhances low-temperature NH3-SCR activity. Furthermore, the co-doping of WO3 and MoO3 significantly affected the migration and aggregation of vanadium species, converting surface monomeric vanadium oxide species into surface polymeric vanadium oxide species. Polymeric vanadium oxide species are crucial for enhancing the NH3-SCR activity of the catalyst, with a high proportion of these species significantly boosting the NH3-SCR activity under low-temperature conditions.
